metadata.title: Calf Strain
anatomical location body part affected: Posterior lower leg muscles/gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, or flexor hallucis longus
description: Anatomy review(5) –The posterior compartment of the leg contains the superficial and deep compartments. When referring to calf strain, most authors are referring to the muscles of the superficial compartment, also known as the triceps surae: the gastrocnemius (with its medial and lateral heads), plantaris, and soleus

A calf-muscle  strain injury (CMSI) is a muscle injury due to fiber tearing, usually in the mid-section  of the calf. The medial gastrocnemius is most often affected. The lateral gastrocnemius, soleus, plantaris, and flexor hallucis longus muscles (part of the deep posterior compartment) may also be involved(5)
Fibers typically tear in the muscle belly or in the gastrocnemius-soleus  myotendinous complex(5)

Grading the severity of CMSI(6) –1st degree: tearing of relatively few fibers -The muscle is stretched, causing micro tears in the muscle fibers. Recovery takes approximately 2 to 4 weeks –2nd degree: partial tearing of many muscle fibers; muscle and tendon remain partly intact -Full recovery takes approximately 4 to 8 weeks –3rd degree: The most severe CMSI, with a complete tearing or rupture of muscle fibers (See Clinical Review…Achilles Tendon Rupture ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708413) -Obvious muscle defect/deformity -Surgery is often needed to repair the rupture site -Return to sport may take months

Acute injury is most likely CMSI to gastrocnemius or plantaris and is associated with quick, sharp movement during sprinting or jumping. As it was first observed in lawn tennis players, CMSI is also known as “tennis leg.” Soleus injuries have a more gradual onset, typically within 24 hours of precipitating even, and are associated with fatigue and overtraining(5)
The differential diagnosis should include deep vein thrombosis (DVT) when pain and swelling are near the popliteal fossa(5)
Specific evidence-based  treatment guidelines for CMSI are lacking. Most research onCMSI is in athletes, especially runners  or application of equipment . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures

ICD-10 codes.S86.1: injury of other muscle(s) and tendon(s) of posterior muscle group at lower leg level
ICD-10 codes.S83.6: sprain and strain of other and unspecified parts of knee (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific reimbursement issues or information regarding CMSI has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Tenderness to palpation in specific areas can indicate which muscle is involved: –Gastrocnemius - distal insertion of the medial or lateral head into the proximal Achilles fascia –Soleus - deep and often distal to the muscle bellies ofthe gastrocnemius on either medial or lateral leg –Popliteus - commonly localized along the medial posterior tibial border or shin or along the tarsal tunnel
Milder injuries: –Tenderness to palpation –Pain with MMT –No swelling, discoloration, or defects
More severe injuries: –Significant tenderness to palpation –Discoloration and swelling –Sometimes a visible defect Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stop evaluation and refer to physician if signs of DVT (e.g., positive Homans’ test, decreased distal pulses) or myositis ossificans are found
Follow surgeon’s postoperative protocol, if applicable
Inform physician if activation or squeezing of calf muscle does not plantar flex foot (i.e., the Thompson’s test is positive for complete rupture of Achilles tendon)
Avoid tests and maneuvers that evoke the patient’s pain

causes: The medial head of the gastrocnemius is often injured in one explosive episode (e.g., sprinting or jumping)(5)

Mechanism of injury may involve passive or active overloading/overstretching(5)–Eccentric (lengthening) contraction when landing on toes, as in sprinting or stepping down from a curb or stairs–Explosive calf muscle contractions with bursts of speed, as in tennis (and other racket sports), jumping, running uphill,and soccer
Repetitive subacute microtrauma that extends a tear over time, as in tennis, running, soccer, jumping sports, andbasketball(5)
Soleus injuries are typically due to overuse and occur as a result of repetitive dorsiflexion of the ankle with knee bent (e.g.,uphill running)

overall contraindications precautions: Returning to sport before adequate calf muscle strengthening and sport-specific  conditioning increases risk of recurrence
Notify physician if numbness, tingling, or weakness is found distal to the injury
Consider the possibility that a DVT is associated with the patient’s posterior leg pain
Increased risk of myositis ossificans (see Clinical Review on this topic) in cases of muscle contusion resulting from direct blow or trauma to the calf
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Stop evaluation and refer to physician if signs of DVT (e.g., positive Homans’ test, decreased distal pulses) or myositis ossificans are found
Follow surgeon’s postoperative protocol, if applicable
Inform physician if activation or squeezing of calf muscle does not plantar flex foot (i.e., the Thompson’s test is positive for complete rupture of Achilles tendon)
Avoid tests and maneuvers that evoke the patient’s pain

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Commonly related to sports or work. Abrupt onset of moderate to severe sharp calf pain during physical activity, followed by reduced ambulatory function. Patient may recall a sudden tearing sensation or hearing a “pop” in the calf(5)

course of treatment.medical management: What acute care did the patient receive? Did patient have restricted weight-bearing  (WB)? What are the ongoing limitations in daily activities? Are symptoms subsiding?
course of treatment.medications: What medications, if any, were prescribed, and are these being taken and effectively controlling symptoms? Oral NSAIDs often are prescribed for pain and swelling in early stage
diagnostic tests completed: Soft tissue diagnostic ultrasound or MRI may be used to identify a severe tear or rupture. MRI is used only if the diagnosis is unclear, as ultrasound has been found to be just as effective in diagnosing CMSI
o Authors of a review of the literature on ultrasound diagnosis of calf injuries found that(7)
two-thirds  of calf injuries occur at the junction of the fascia between the medial head of the gastrocnemius and the soleus
injuries to the lateral head of the gastrocnemius occur in up to 14% of patients
A D-dimer  blood test may be ordered if a blood clot is suspected
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document these factors and the length of time before the symptoms come on or are eased
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if applicableDocument the use of supplemental oxygen and assistance with ventilation
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., low back pain, knee pain, hip pain) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any history of CMSI or posterior leg pain?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other ongoing conditions (e.g., diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic problems)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms being experienced

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Is the patient an athlete? If so, consider involving the coach in the maintenance phase of rehabilitation and the return to sport
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home; does patient live with a caregiver? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) Compare all abnormal test results with uninjured side
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document patient’s height, weight, and BMI
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for and proper use of ambulatory assistive devices
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess balance in standing, walking on toes (as applicable), and timed single-leg  stance. Look for deficits in ankle strategies to maintain balance. Use Berg Balance Scale (BBS) for objective measure, as applicable
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulses distal to affected areaAssess for swelling with circumference measure. Unilateral pitting edema can be a sign of DVT
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess ability in transfers, standing, walking, stairs, carrying, etc. Timed Up-and-Go  (TUG) test. Use the FIM, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for antalgic gait. Expect shortened step length on injured side. Use Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) for objective measure, as applicableThe intrinsic joint mobility of knee and ankle should not be affected by this condition
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess strength of lower extremity using manual muscle testing (MMT), especially of plantar flexors in knee extension and knee flexion. Expect pain and weakness in most cases. Increased pain with knee extended is consistent with gastrocnemius strain, whereas no change in pain with the knee extended suggests a soleus strain. Assess ability to perform single-leg  heel raise. Strength of ankle dorsiflexors should be similar to unaffected side
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess general posture, lower extremity alignment, and leg length in standing. Partial WB on injured side may affect findings
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROM of ankle in sitting and prone positions. Note if calf pain limits ROM
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess patellar tendon and Achilles tendon reflexes
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –Lower Extremity Function Scale (LEFS)  –Thompson’s test (i.e., squeeze patient’s calf while lying in prone – resulting plantarflexion movement normal and lack of plantarflexion abnormal) has been shown to be 96% sensitive and has a 98% positive predictive value for Achilles rupture(11)

contraindications precautions: Over an area of circulatory compromise
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Avoid applying cold over superficial nerves
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young or very old
Over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Over infected areas where infection may spread or cross-contamination  may occur
Over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
Application in any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner

Electrodes should not be placed over: -the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators -the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region in pregnant women -carotid bodies -phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators -areas of known peripheral vascular disease including arterial or venous thrombosis or thrombophlebitis -the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -areas of active osteomyelitis -areas of hemorrhage

Electrotherapy should be used with caution -in patients without intact sensation -in patients who are unable to communicate -in patients with compromised mental status -in patients with cardiac dysfunction -in patients with epilepsy
Electrodes should not be placed -over neoplasms -over compromised skin -over tissues vulnerable to hemorrhage or hematoma -over the cervical or craniofacial region
Pregnancy—over the abdomen or low back
Active bone growth at the epiphysis
Cancer—over a known or suspected area of malignancy
pregnancy  over the abdomen or low back
Cancer  over a known or suspected area of malignancy
Active bone growth at the epiphysis
Skin disease, including damaged and at-risk  skin
Spinal cord and superficial or regenerating nerves
other: Patients with painful and weak calf function are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Evaluate fall risk

Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Whirlpool precautions (*some are relevant only if entire body is immersed)(1)

Electrotherapy contraindications  (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(1)
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications for continuous US(1)
Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications for pulsed US(1)
Therapeutic ultrasound precautions for pulsed US(1)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CMSI/pain on exertion, limitations in ROM, strength, gait, and functional mobility. Intervention is indicated to return patient safely to daily activities and sport
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Achilles tendon rupture (partial or complete)(5) Popliteal injury – usually associated with downhill running/walking. Pain is commonly localized along the medial posterior tibial border or shin or along the tarsal tunnel(5) Plantaris rupture Achilles tendinopathy(5) DVT(5) Ruptured Baker’s or popliteal cyst(6) Claudication – peripheral arterial disease Sciatica and lumbar radiculopathy Compartment syndrome(5) Popliteal artery entrapment(5) – mimics soleus injury
prognosis: Functional outcomes are excellent in 1st degree strain and good in 2nd degree strain, whereas complete rupture is generally not associated with full recovery of strength, flexibility, or sports performance(6)
Injuries to the central soleus aponeurosis tend to heal more slowly than tears in the medial and lateral calf(3)

Healing time for CMSI may be up to 6 weeks before the athlete can safely return to regular training.(4) Other sources estimate 3 to 4 months, depending on severity.(5) It should be kept in mind that a prior CMSI is a risk factor for a recurring CMSI(8,9) ›Referral to other disciplines  (as indicated)
Orthopedic surgeon for surgical consult in 3rd degree strain cases
Podiatrist for involvement of the affected foot
Orthotist for orthotic or CAM walker
Physical therapist trained in functional dry needling
other considerations: Muscle fiber regeneration time varies according to the degree of strain. Limit the period of immobilization to the time needed to restore sufficient strength for safe therapeutic exercise. Restrict physical activity to avoid pain. An athlete’s safe return to sport may take months, depending on the degree of strain(5)

Some research has looked at the timing of beginning treatment after injury. The following was reported when 50 amateur athletes with severe acute injury of the thigh muscle or calf muscle either started treatment 2 days after injury or 9 days after injury: –All the patients in this Danish RCT completed daily repeated static stretching in week one of the protocol, daily isometric loading with increasing load (weeks 2 to 4), dynamic loading with increasing resistance 3 times per week (weeks 5 to 8), and functional exercises combined with heavy strength training 3 times per week (weeks 9 to 12).There were no differences reported in MRI measurements (measuring tissue inflammation and perfusion) or strength measures between  groups, although there was a trend in the early rehabilitation group toward having less pain and more confidence in their abilities(12) –An earlier RCT by the same group showed that patients who received early rehabilitation were able to return to play significantly sooner than patients who received the later rehabilitation (median of 62.5 days versus 83 days, respectively)(13)
treatment summary: In general, earlier therapy may produce more satisfaction, less pain, and earlier return to sport(12,13)

Acute phase: control ROM and restrict specific activities that provoke pain, but prevent unnecessary immobilization. Try gentle seated active plantar flexion and dorsiflexion. Encourage WB as tolerated. Recommend that the patient treat pain and swelling using PRICE using PRICE (protection, rest, icing, compression, elevation) approach 2–4 times daily(6)

Physical agents/mechanical modalities: The effectiveness of cryotherapy, ultrasound, or electrostimulation for CMSI rehabilitation has not been investigated in randomized controlled studies. Heat pack or therapeutic ultrasound may help increase tissue elasticity prior to stretching or manual therapy
Calf compression sleeves and heel lifts in the shoeduring the early phases of treatment may be helpful to reduce swelling, provide support, and accommodate the shortened muscle(5,6)

Strengthening exercises –In subacute phase (7 days post injury): try submaximal isometric ankle plantar flexion in seated position at multiple angles with minimal pain –In late-subacute  phase (> 14 days): progress to concentric exercises (try ankle submaximal plantar flexion in seated position with ankle weights); single-leg  balance with opposite leg swings, half squats, walking lunges, and balance board exercises; gait reeducation, and proprioceptive training, as needed
Stretching exercises: in subacute phase, progress ankle plantar flexion ROM (without increasing pain); long-term therapeutic goal is to match flexibility of the contralateral side

Functional training: progress to dynamic ankle plantar flexion exercises using elastic bands or tubing, one-footed  hops, duck walk, run forward and backward at half speed, jog figure-8s  at half speed(6)
Sports-specific  training: gradually progress running at speeds to near-maximal.  Add agility running, jumping, and drills specific to sport(5)
Manual therapy: gentle soft-tissue  work to mobilize hematoma and adhesions, effleurage for swelling
Patient education for self-care  and implementing an independent exercise program

Due to the biomechanical differences seen in patients with recurrent CMSI, it has been suggested that addressing pelvis and hip kinematics may reduce the demands placed upon the calf complex(10) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain, tenderness, swelling, and bruisingResolve pain, edema, and ecchymosis _ _ Protect healing structuresPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Use of cryotherapeutic agents and the PRICE formula in acute phase _ _ Prescription and application of ambulatory devices/ equipment for 2nd and 3rd degree strainsWean from devices Provide the patient with simple instructions for PRICE  Calf muscle weakness and reduced ROM in ankle plantar flexionMaximize (preferably normalize) ankle strength and flexibilityTherapeutic modalities _ Strengthening and stretching exercises, as indicated (see Treatment summary , above)Gradual progression of weight-bearing and intensity of exercises, allowing patient to bear additional weight. Progress to eccentric ankle strengthening exercisesProvide the patient with exercises for ROM and strengthening. Daily repetition of exercises Painful or nonsymmetrical weight-bearing. Reduced functional mobilitySymmetry in standing posture and weight- bearing activities. Maximized ambulatory function and return to regular activities, including sports for athletesFunctional training _ Posture, gait, and mobility training. Balance and proprioception training. Sport specific training, as indicated _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Ambulatory assistive devices may be prescribed, as neededProgression of task- specific exercises to achieve goalsProvide patient and family/caregivers with written instructions regarding functional activities that can be performed at home and correct use and/ or application of equipment .

maintenance or prevention: Increase calf flexibility and eccentric single-leg  strength(6)
